content:
• Thursday, March 30, 2017
  • P

    Pandora extends board nomination deadline yet again

    • Pandora Media (P -1.6%) has again extended a deadline for nominations to its board, with increasing likelihood that it faces a proxy fight.
    • In a filing, the company says it's amended by-laws to extend the date to April 14. That's after a previous extension to March 17 and one stretching it to March 31.
    • Recently, founder Tim Westergren has said the company's not for sale and that it will achieve profitability this year.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:04 PM | 2 Comments
  • WIN

    Windstream plans expansion of Detroit metro fiber network

    • Windstream Holdings (WIN +1.9%) is pursuing a "major" expansion of its Detroit metro fiber network.
    • The company's short on details, but the expansion will include fiber along with fixed wireless in order to connect the company's national network with major data-center complexes and commercial buildings in the area.
    • It's not only expanding the footprint, Windstream says, but also services available, "including fixed wireless service, unified communications, managed services, network security, business continuity, network solutions and cloud services."
    • Similar expansions are planned for Charlotte, Nashville, Richmond, Little Rock, Atlanta, Chicago, Minneapolis, Philadelphia, Dallas, St. Louis and Cleveland.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:29 PM | 7 Comments
  • FTR

    Frontier expands Texas broadband offering by 25,000 households

    • Frontier Communications (FTR +5.5%) says it's leveraged federal funding to help it make enhanced broadband available to another 25,000 Texas households.
    • The company is using the Connect America Fund, designed to subsidize rural broadband, to supply about 5,500 households in eligible census blocks, along with expanded reach to another 20,000 households.
    • As of last year, Frontier began receiving about $16M annually from the CAF in order to expand Texas locations to 37,208 by the end of 2020.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:17 PM | 3 Comments
  • XSPA

    FORM Holdings -6% after fiscal-year report

    • FORM Holdings (FH) is slipping in the postmarket session, down 6% after an earnings report where IP revenue fell by half but promising new revenue streams came from growth in XpresSpa and Group Mobile.
    • Fiscal year revenue by segment: XpresSpa, $811K (new); Group Mobile, $6.64M (up 610%); FLI Charge, $350K (up from previous $2K); Intellectual property, $11.18M (down 48.6%).
    • The company says it plans to grow revenues for recently acquired XpresSpa through store expansion as well as comp store sales increases, while Group Mobile can be grown with new products, new regions and new distribution verticals (including military and government).
    • For FLI Charge, it expects to enhance IP rights and "strengthen and develop partnerships in numerous markets including automotive, education, office, healthcare, power tools and vaporizers."
    • Cash balance at Dec. 31 was $17.9M.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 5:58 PM | 5 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers: CNAT +5.4%. NQ +4.8%. VJET +3.5%. EGLE +3.3%. SUN +1.9%.
    • Top losers: PTI -13.2%. FRSH -4.6%. NH -3.7%. HPQ -2.1%. GGB -1.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 1 Comment
  • VJET

    Voxeljet +4.9% after Q4 earnings

    • Voxeljet (NYSE:VJET) is up 4.9% following a Q4 report where revenues dipped and missed, but the company stuck to its forecast for full-year sales.
    • Revenue of €6.28M missed an expected €6.83M. Systems revenues fell 19.7%, to €3.93M, while services revenues dropped 30.7% to €2.34M.
    • Gross profit, meanwhile, was up in Services (to €875K from a loss of €337K), and down in Systems (to €379K from €2M).
    • Backlog of 3D printer orders at Dec. 31 was €3.78M -- representing five printers. That's vs. a backlog of €5.6M (nine printers) the prior year.
    • Cash and equivalents at year's end were €7.85M and the company had €12.58M in bond funds and a note receivable.
    • For Q1, the company's guiding to revenue of €4.25M-€4.75M, and it reaffirms full-year guidance for revenues of €26M-€28M, gross margin over 40%, capex of €8M-€9M and EBITDA neutral to positive.
    • Conference call to come tomorrow at 8:30 a.m. ET.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 5:11 PM | 3 Comments

    Cytosorbents slides 9% on capital raise

    • The size of the share sale isn't disclosed. Cowen is the sole underwriter.

  • PSTI

    Pluristem +5% as talks for Japan JV progress

    • Pluristem Therapeutics (NASDAQ:PSTI) gets closer towards the formation of a new corporation with Sosei Corporate Venture Capital to pursue development and commercialization of the PLX-PAD cell therapy product in Japan.
    • A definitive deal should be announced in coming months, rather than by March 31 as previously announced.
    • Shares +5% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:43 PM
  • BTX

    Positive coverage lifts BioTime and MacroGenics post-close

    • Volume isn't huge, but BioTime (NYSEMKT:BTX) is higher by 3.9%, and MacroGenics (NASDAQ:MGNX) by 1.5% after Raymond James initiates coverage on both with Outperform ratings.
    • The $6 price target on BTX suggests more than 80% upside, and the $26 price target on MGNX suggests nearly 50% upside.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:38 PM | 3 Comments
  • AKTX

    Akari Therapeutics gains more than 8% on Fast Track status for Coversin

    • The company's Coversin for treatment of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria in patients who have polymorphisms conferring eculizumab resistance has won Fast Track designation by the FDA.
    • AKTX +8.7% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:34 PM

    DarioHealth tumbles 17% on share sale

    • DRIO -17% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM

    Orex Therapeutics -7.2% on capital raise plan

    • With underwriter Cantor Fitzgerald, the company sets an ATM offering for up to $20M of stock.
    • OREX -7.2% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:28 PM | 6 Comments
  • TTPH

    Tetraphase Pharma +1.25% after research funding

    • Tetraphase Pharmaceuticals' (NASDAQ:TTPH) pipeline candidate TP-6076 was selected to receive $4M in research funding from the Combating Antibiotic Resistant Bacteria Biopharmaceutical Accelerator (CARB-X).
    • Tetraphase CEO Guy Macdonald notes the "exceptional in vitro potency against two of the most dangerous organisms, carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) and carbapenem-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii (CRAB)."
    • Shares +1.25% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM
  • BLRX

    BioLineRx -14% on capital raise

    • The company announces a secondary offering of ADSs, with JMP Securities underwriting.
    • BLRX -14% after hours

  • UNXL

    Uni-Pixel misses by $0.05, revenue in-line

    • Uni-Pixel (NASDAQ:UNXL): Q4 EPS of -$0.16 misses by $0.05.
    • Revenue of $1.4M (+57.3% Y/Y) in-line.
    • Shares +1.65%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM | 8 Comments
  • FCX

    Workers to end strike at Freeport McMoRan's top Peru copper mine

    • Workers at Freeport McMoRan's (FCX +4.6%) Cerro Verde copper mine in Peru will resume work on Friday after voting to end a nearly three-week strike, the union says.
    • The union claims the strike has disrupted the mine's production of ~40K metric tons/month of copper, although FCX has said there was no material impact on production.
    • The news comes amid increased hopes that FCX soon could resume exports from its Grasberg copper mine in Indonesia.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 4 Comments
  • TGNA

    FCC to vote on reversing station-ownership rules

    • The FCC will vote in April on another Obama-era reversal, to effectively overturn limits on the number of TV stations that some companies can buy.
    • Rules set last year didn't require any company to sell existing stations, but could slow some anticipated acquisitions -- notably a megadeal combo of Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI +2.4%) and rival broadcaster Tribune Media (TRCO +0.8%).
    • Chairman Ajit Pai is offering a plan to bring back the "UHF Discount" used in calculating station counts for the limit. Before it was revoked last year, the discount let station groups half-count UHF stations (those higher than channel 13 on the old frequency dial).
    • The FCC had killed the discount on the logic that the old VHF-UHF comparison on strength was moot after the digital TV conversion.
    • Also moving: TGNA +0.8%; NXST +2.3%; CBS +1.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:47 PM | 8 Comments
  • GPN

    Global Payments hits all-time high as Barclays goes Overweight

    • Global Payments (NYSE:GPN) is up 2.5% today and hit an all-time high following a boost to Overweight from Barclays.
    • Analyst Darrin Peller says the company will post "cleaner" organic growth in Q2, and beat expectations for a 90-basis point margin expansion.
    • It could also beat and raise on expectations of 20% EPS growth.
    • Among Peller's reasons: Lower attrition and synergies at Heartland, possible M&A (in 2018, or otherwise buying back stock), and better currency comparisons.
    • He boosted his price target on shares to $92 from $88, implying 14% upside from current levels.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:36 PM
  • BSET

    More on Bassett Furniture's FQ1

    • Bassett Furniture (BSET -1.3%) reports comparable-store sales rose 1% in FQ1.
    • Wholesale segment revenue grew 4% to $62M.
    • Retail segment revenue increased 5.5% to $61.6M.
    • Logistical services revenue dropped 9.7% to $22.3M.
    • The gross margin rate fell 30 bps to 60.4%.
    • Operating margin rate down 100 bps to 4.4%.
    • Store Count -1 Q/Q to 89.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:40 PM

  • Technology - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2:30 pm

  • MNST

    Monster's Hydro product delayed - Wells Fargo

    • Monster Beverage (MNST -1.8%) sinks further for the session on a Wells Fargo note saying its new Hydro product has been delayed, potentially indefinitely.
    • Wells: "We have concerns about the ability for Monster’s new innovation to have any meaningful impact on sales this year."
    • via Notable Calls
     
     
     
     
    | 2:33 PM | 3 Comments

  • Energy/Materials - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: BCEI +12%. COP +7%. FCX +5%. SAEX +5%.
    • Losers: CVE -13%. GEVO -11%. WOR -10%. GBR -7%. MBII -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM
  • EXTR

    Analysts boost targets on Extreme Networks, now up 19% after Brocade deal

    • Extreme Networks (NASDAQ:EXTR) zoomed in postmarket trade yesterday after news it was buying Brocade's data-center networking business, and it's up a healthy 19% to its highest point in more than 10 years as analysts boost targets.
    • A $55M cash purchase will generate more than $230M in incremental annualized revenue, Extreme says -- a bargain that made sense for Broadcom/Brocade since it would supply many of the parts for the business, as Wunderlich notes.
    • Extreme is "the next major networking player," says Wunderlich's Matthew Robison, who has boosted his price target to $9 from $8 (implying 18% upside from today's elevated pricing).
    • Needham has a $9.50 price target, up from $7, noting the deal "paves the way for the company to be a competitive player in the large enterprise data center market, including edge routing."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:54 PM
  • SSI

    Stage Stores rallies after striking deal for Gordmans Stores

    • Stage Stores (SSI +9.3%) announces that it will acquire select assets of Gordmans Stores out of bankruptcy.
    • Under the terms of the transaction, a Stage subsidiary acquire a minimum of 50 Gordmans store leases, with rights to assume leases for an additional seven stores and a distribution center.
    • The company intends to fund the transaction and related investments from existing cash and availability under its credit facility.
    • “We believe the Gordmans business model offers great potential and, without the burden of a high level of debt, unprofitable locations and an oversized infrastructure, we expect the Gordmans business will be accretive to our earnings," says Stage CEO Michael Glazer.
    • Source: Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 1:15 PM | 1 Comment
  • GVA

    California transportation bill could spark Granite Construction, analyst says

    • Granite Construction (GVA +4%) is higher following a positive note from Cowen analyst Joseph Giordano, who thinks a California transportation bill could restore momentum in the shares.
    • Giordano says California Gov. Brown and state legislative leaders have set a deadline of April 6 to pass transportation funding bill that could bring a roughly tripling of the budget increase to the California Department of Transportation, GVA's largest customer, according to TheFly.com.
    • GVA rallied post-election but has since reversed even as a California bill is poised to be passed, but Giordano thinks clarity in California could help the stock; Cowen rates GVA at Outperform with a $70 price target.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:56 PM | 1 Comment
  • FTR

    Frontier Communications +5% in rebound

    • Frontier Communications (NYSE:FTR) -- recently in the doldrums after a Goldman Sachs downgrade and its ouster from the S&P 500 -- is up 5% today with a number of big block trades coming in.
    • Volume overall has surpassed 33M, vs. a recent daily average of 58.3M.
    • The company has amended its June 2014 credit agreement with additions providing that interest rate margins under its facilities will range from 0.875% to 3.875% for base-rate borrowings, and from 1.875% to 4.875% for Libor borrowings.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 17 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: PRAN +38%. ATHX +25%. XBIO +23%. LPTH +20%. EXTR +18%. CVGI +16%. XELB +14%. BVXV +14%. ACST +11%. IDXG +11%.
    • Losers: OTC:CRTN -28%. LULU -23%. TNXP -17%. IDN -16%. EXFO -14%. SAIC -13%. CVE -12%. HALO -12%. KBSF -11%. ROSG-OLD -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 10 Comments
  • IONS

    Ionis Pharma's Akcea launches mid-stage study of dyslipidemia candidate to identify dosage regimen for late-stage cardiovascular outcomes study; shares ahead 3%

    • Ionis Pharmaceuticals' (IONS +3%) Akcea Therapeutics initiates a 270-subject Phase 2b dose-ranging study of AKCEA-APO(a)-Lrx in patients with hyperlipoproteinemia (a) and established cardiovascular disease. The aim of the trial is the clarify the dose level and frequency for a planned Phase 3 cardiovascular outcome study. Top-line data should be available in mid-2018.
    • AKCEO-APO(a)-Lrx, along with AKCEA-APOIII-Lrx, is part of Akcea's collaboration with Novartis. Both are antisense drugs to treat lipid disorders.
    • Lp(a) is a lipoprotein particle assembled in the liver that is associated with an increased risk of coronary heart disease. ApoC-III is a protein produced in the liver that plays a key role in the regulation of serum triglycerides.
    • Previously: Ionis and subsidiary Akcea collaborate with Novartis to develop two cardiovascular candidates in deal valued as high as $1.7B; Ionis up 8% premarket (Jan. 6)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:44 PM | 5 Comments
  • CMTL

    Comtech Telecom gets follow-on military contract for $6.6M

    • Comtech Telecommunications (CMTL +1.7%) has secured a follow-on contract for more than $6.6M covering high-power satellite communication traveling wave tube amplifiers (TWTAs).
    • The deal came between Comtech's subsidiary Xicom (part of its Commercial Solutions segment) and a U.S. military integrator.
    • It's the third multi-year award for such power amplifiers.
    • Xicom makes a number of tube-based and solid-state amplifiers for satellite uplinks, including power levels from 8 W to 3 kW, in frequencies from 2 GHz to 45 GHz.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:30 PM
  • AA

    Alcoa +3% on Rio Tinto takeover chatter

    • Alcoa (AA +3.1%) pops higher amid chatter that bankers are working with Rio Tinto (RIO +0.7%) on a potential takeover bid for the company, according to TheFly.com.
    • There is no known basis for the rumor at present, and no specifics are available, but shares are up on heavier than normal volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:21 PM | 11 Comments

  • Consumer - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: XELB +14%. ROX +8%. VUZI +6%. OBCI +6%.
    • Losers: LULU -23%. KBSF -10%. ZX -7%. TIS -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:02 PM
  • RF

    Big bounce in banks to end the month

    • The formerly red-hot banking sector had been down 10% this month, but today continues to bounce from the lows hit at the open on Monday.
    • The SPDR Regional Banking ETF (NYSEARCA:KRE) is higher by 2.75% this session and the SPDR KBW Bank ETF (NYSEARCA:KBE) up 2.4%. This against an S&P 500 up just 0.25%.
    • Higher yields may be helping - the 10-year Treasury is up 2 basis points to 2.40%. Also a catalyst is the idea that the president doesn't need Congress to push through large chunks of his eased regulatory agenda.
    • Regional players on the move include: Regions Financial (RF +2.4%), Huntington Bancshares (HBAN +2%), KeyCorp (KEY +2.3%), Fifth Third (FITB +2.7%), Valley National (VLY +2.7%), Zions (ZION +2.4%), Comerica (CMA +2.2%), PNC Financial (PNC +1.5%).
     
     
     
     
    | 11:55 AM
  • CVE

    Cenovus Energy -11% as massive deal seen increasing debt, leverage

    • Cenovus Energy (CVE -11.5%) slumps to 52-week lows following its purchase of ConocoPhillips’ (COP +8.7%) Canadian assets catapults, which catapults the company into the top three in the oil sands but the amount of debt it is taking on is raising red flags.
    • CEO Brian Ferguson called the deal “a unique opportunity to take full control of our oil sands assets,” during a conference call, adding that it would double CVE’s total production and reserves; he also said CVE plans to sell off its Pelican Lake oil sands properties and some light oil assets in Alberta as a result of the deal, and the company would revisit its dividend once those assets sold.
    • But analysts say the deal will weigh on shares in the near-term; Raymond James' Chris Cox says CVE takes on a “noticeably higher risk profile” after the deal, and investors are unlikely to see any appeal in the decision to deploy capital towards acquisitions rather than buybacks.
    • Morgan Stanley's Benny Wong says the deal simplifies CVE's operating structure and decision making, and buying producing assets that are familiar and top-tier is a “much more welcome scenario for the market rather than accelerating spend to develop new projects and have to wait several years before seeing cash flow.”
    • Canaccord's Dennis Fong says the price paid for the assets is fair, but the diversification from oil sands may confuse investors, yet he sees a sound strategic basis in acquiring assets which can aid in showing short-cycle growth and provide a source for natural gas liquids.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:42 AM | 10 Comments
  • VEON

    VimpelCom shareholders approve rebranding to VEON

    • VimpelCom (VIP +2%) has gotten shareholder approval for its name change to VEON.
    • The company set the change to signal its transition from strictly mobile telecom to more general global technology.
    • It's also amending by-laws to "improve the efficiency of decision-making" while ensuring there's still satisfactory Supervisory Board oversight, it says.
    • With approval secured at today's special meeting, the company will trade on Nasdaq as VEON starting tomorrow.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:36 AM
  • CM

    CIBC boosts bid for PrivateBancorp; shares climb 6%

    • The deal would now be for $24.20 in cash and 0.4176 shares of CIBC (CM -1.7%) for each share of PrivateBancorp (PVTB +5.8%). Based on yesterday's close, it values PVTB at $4.9B, or $60.92 per share - 20% higher than the initial terms from last summer, and valuing the company at 2.7x tangible book value.
    • The deal is hoped to close in Q2.
    • Not enough, says KBW's Chris McGratty. He says PVTB is worth $70.
    • Barclays' John Aiken says the new offer is plenty, and that CIBC owners probably won't like it.
    • PVTB's gain today puts the stock at $59.47.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:33 AM | 5 Comments
  • PRAN

    Prana Bio's Parkinson's candidate PBT434 shows encouraging action in preclinical testing; shares jump 43%

    • Ultra-thinly traded nano cap Prana Biotechnology (PRAN +42.7%) rockets on a whopping 427x surge in volume in response to its announcement of positive preclinical on Parkinson's disease candidate PBT434. The results are being presented at the 13th International Conference for Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Diseases in Vienna, Austria.
    • The poster presents in vivo evidence of the ability of PBT434 to prevent the loss of neurons that cause motor and cognitive dysfunction by preventing the degenerative processes that lead to neuron cell death.
    • PBT434 lowers the accumulation of a key protein called alpha-synuclein, which damages the nerve cells of the substantia nigra part of the part of the brain where movement is controlled.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:14 AM | 11 Comments
  • FSRL

    First Solar completes sale of 250 MW Nevada power plant

    • First Solar (OTCPK:FSRL) says it completed the sale of the 250 MW Moapa Southern Paiute solar power plant in Nevada to a unit of Swiss asset manager Capital Dynamics for an unspecified sum.
    • Minority tax equity interests in the project are shared by GE Energy Financial Services and a Goldman Sachs affiliate.
    • FSLR says it will continue to operate and maintain the power plant, which has a 25-year power purchase agreement with the Los Angeles Department of Water & Power.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:11 AM | 2 Comments
  • FCX

    Freeport McMoRan may be nearing export deal with Indonesia; shares +5%

    • Freeport McMoRan (FCX +5.5%) is close to reaching a deal that would allow it to temporarily resume copper concentrate exports from its Grasberg mine, Indonesia's mining minister says.
    • FCX would be allowed to resume exports for the next six months while continuing to negotiate fiscal terms for the new permit, the minister says, adding that the discussions would be handled by Indonesia's finance ministry and would focus on its request for a "nailed down" tax rate and guarantees that other fiscal terms would not change.
    • The government halted FCX's concentrate exports in mid January in an attempt to improve revenues from mining resources and create jobs, but the change in tone could signal that the 10-week stoppage of exports from the world's second-biggest copper mine is near an end.
    • ETFs: JJC, CPER, CUPM
     
     
     
     
    | 10:58 AM | 41 Comments
  • ROX

    Castle Brands +95% YTD on ginger beer buzz

    • Castle Brands (ROX +10.3%) announces that it acquired an additional 20.1% stake in Gosling-Castle Partners Inc.
    • GCP holds the exclusive long-term export and distribution rights for Goslings Rum and Goslings Stormy Ginger Beer for all countries other than Bermuda.
    • The transaction increases Castle Brands ownership of GCP to 80.1%.
    • "We believe that our sales and marketing initiatives will enhance Goslings Rum sales and that the strong growth of Goslings Stormy Ginger Beer will expand the consumer base, grow brand awareness and drive more consumer pull," says Castle Brands COO John Glover.
    • Shares of Castle Brands are now up 95% YTD as the company's new distribution deal with Wal-Mart continues to create a buzz.
    • Source: Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 10:50 AM | 13 Comments
  • JILL

    Post-IPO high for J. Jill Group

    • J. Jill Group (JILL +2.3%) impresses with a 10.8% increase in comparable store sales during Q4 and guidance for a high single digit comp for Q1.
    • The retailer, which has a thriving e-commerce business, saw direct to consumer sales increase to 48.8% of total sales vs. 46.1% last year.
    • Adjusted EBITDA was up 46% Y/Y to $22.5M in Q4.
    • J. Jill jumped to a post-IPO high of $13.71 today. Wall Street firms are still quiet on the stock, but several Seeking Alpha contributors have articles dissecting the upside potential.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:40 AM
  • WINS

    40-bagger Wins Finance slips 16% as analysts have a look

    • At one point earlier this year, shares of the company - a small-business loan and leasing company in China - were up more than 4,000% since debuting on the Nasdaq late in 2015.
    • At the peak, Wins' (WINS -16.1%) market cap was $9B, or four times that of Lending Club, a lender with 50x the revenue.
    • What gives? Bloomberg takes a look today, as does Seeking Alpha contributor Fuzzy Panda Shorts, who calls the "highly manipulated" stock a zero.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:38 AM | 26 Comments

  • Natural gas inventory draw at par with consensus

    • EIA Natural Gas Inventory: -43 Bcf vs. -42 Bcf consensus, -150 Bcf last week.
    • Futures -1.21% to $3.192.
    • ETFs: UNG, DGAZ, UGAZ, BOIL, GAZ, KOLD, UNL, DCNG
     
     
     
     
    | 10:30 AM | 30 Comments
  • COP

    ConocoPhillips +6.5% as divestiture seen as big win for shareholders

    • ConocoPhillips (COP +6.4%) is the top gainer on the S&P 500 in early trading amid widespread praise for the sale of its 50% interest in the FCCL partnership with Cenovus Energy (CVE -10.6%), as it allows for debt reduction and share buybacks.
    • Cowen analyst Charles Robertson says some investors were skeptical of COP's plan announced in November to sell $3B-$5B in assets and buy back $3B worth of stock, but the "unexpected big deal" with CVE accomplished the plan in less than a year.
    • UBS upgrades shares to Buy from Neutral with a $55 price target, up from $51, saying COP is divesting a “low growth, low margin asset that will enable it to immediately reduce its debt load by ~$7B," and the deal improves COP’s production mix with lower margin bitumen dropping to 5% from 15% as higher margin oil increases to 40% from 35%.
    • Evercore ISI says the deal creates “significant value," and appears accretive to return on equity, earnings and cash margins; analyst Doug Terreson says COP management is leading Big Oil and the E&P industry on positive, shareholder oriented change.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:24 AM | 37 Comments
  • BGCP

    BGC Partners +1.7% after optimistic outlook

    • The company expects both revenues and pre-tax distributable earnings for Q1 to come in near the high-end of previous guidance.
    • Full results are due on May 4.
    • BGCP +1.7%
     
     
     
     
    | 10:18 AM | 2 Comments
  • OFS

    OFS Capital down nearly 6% after raising equity

    • OFS Capital (OFS -5.9%) priced a 3.5M share sale at $14.57 each. December 31 NAV per share was $14.82.
    • The external adviser has agreed to pay the underwriting fee and the $0.25 difference between the offering price and book value, so OFS will see net proceeds of $14.82 per share.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:02 AM | 10 Comments
  • PFMT

    Performant Financial jumps after favorable GAO ruling

    • Performant Financial (PFMT +14.1%) rallies after the company confirms that the General Accounting Office upheld its protest of Department of Education collection decision.
    • A formal written decision is expected within a few days.
    • SEC Form 8-K
     
     
     
     
    | 9:59 AM
  • CF

    CF Industries -3% as Cleveland Research sees weak urea pricing

    • CF Industries (CF -2.8%) opens lower after Cleveland Research turns sharply negative on the shares, as the firm forecasts weakening urea pricing.
    • Cleveland says it is even more cautious on H2 2017 than H1 due to the impact of new capacity additions coming later this year.
    • The firm sees potential near-term downside to $25 for the stock, as it lowers its 2017 EPS outlook to a $0.29 loss vs. Wall Street consensus of $0.63 earnings.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:55 AM | 17 Comments
  • ACST

    Acasti Pharma to proceed with late-stage development of CaPre for the treatment of high triglycerides; shares ahead 7%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Acasti Pharma (ACST +7.1%) is up in early trading, albeit on less than 20K shares, in response to its announcement that it intends to advance lead product candidate CaPre (omega-3 phospholipid) into Phase 3 development for the treatment of patients with hypertriglyceridemia.
    • The company will conduct two pivotal studies in patients with very high blood triglycerides (at least 500 mg/dL). If all goes well, it will file its U.S. marketing application under the abbreviated 505(b)(2) pathway.
    • CaPre is a highly concentrated omega-3 phospholipid, principally EPA and DHA, derived from krill. Acasti says it is absorbed more readily into the body than GlaxoSmithKline's (GSK -0.3%) LOVAZA (omega-3-acid ethyl esters) because the EPA and DHA are naturally free or bound to phospholipids instead of being "esterified."
     
     
     
     
    | 9:46 AM

  • PGNX

    Progenics Pharma's Azedra successful in mid-stage study in rare tumors; shares slump 7% premarket on cloudy nature of data reporting

    • Usually positive trial data gooses stock prices, but not Progenics Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:PGNX). Shares are down 7% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement of positive results from a Phase 2b study assessing Breakthrough Therapy-, Orphan Drug- and Fast Track-tagged AZEDRA (iobenguane I 131) Injection in patients with rare neuroendocrine tumors called pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma.
    • The company says the trial met its primary endpoint of the proportion of participants who achieved at least a 50% reduction in all antihypertensive medication for at least six months. Usually the results are reported as "statistically significant" with a p value no greater than 0.05, but in this case it was reported in terms of the 95% confidence interval (CI), specifically if the lower limit of the two-sided 95% CI was above 10%. The lower limit was 16.15% so it says the study met the primary endpoint per the protocol. The upper limit was 36.52%.
    • Progenics adds that 92.2% of patients who received at least one therapeutic dose of AZEDRA achieved a partial response or stable disease per RECIST criteria.
    • Additional data will be submitted for presentation at a future medical meeting. Management says it will complete its NDA filing by mid-year.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:25 AM | 14 Comments

  • HALO

    Halozyme's PEGPH20 shows no incremental survival benefit in pancreatic cancer study; shares down 11% premarket

    • Halozyme (NASDAQ:HALO) slumps 11% premarket on average volume in response to its announcement that a Phase 1b/2 clinical trial assessing PEGPH20, plus modified FOLFIRINOX chemotherapy, in treatment-naive patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer would be unlikely to show an increase in overall survival (the primary endpoint) compared to FOLIFIRINOX alone. The assessment was made by an independent network of researchers called SWOG.
    • The company is working with SWOG to verify and analyze the data, including an analysis of hyaluronan (HA) level, following the determination of the tumor HA levels.
    • PEGPH20 is an investigational drug administered intravenously that temporarily degrades HA.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:00 AM | 9 Comments

  • LULU

    Analyst pessimism rains down on Lululemon

    • Analysts are reacting to the weak guidance pushed out by Lululemon (NASDAQ:LULU) yesterday alongside its Q4 earnings report.
    • Citi lowers Lululemon to Neutral from Buy on concerns over the productivity comparisions that are upcoming.
    • Wells Fargo moves to Market Perform from Outperform to adjust valuation to the profit guidance from the company. Concerns over margins are raised.
    • Bank of America Merrill Lynch cuts LULU to Underperform from Neutral and chops its price target down to $57. "Slowing sales and moderating [gross margins] puts bull thesis on the mat," says analyst Ira Boruchow.
    • Susquehanna takes the retailer to Neutral from Positive and comes in with a $57 PT.
    • Canaccord takes a victory lap with its Sell rating on LULU into the print looking solid. Analyst Camilo Lyons calls the assortment failure at Lululemon particularly surprising.
